entries.title: Iran Gives Death Sentence to Former Defense Official, a Dual U.K. Citizen
entries.description: Alireza Akbari, a former deputy defense minister, was convicted of spying, in a case he described as a slap at Britain, where he had lived.

entries.title: Your Thursday Briefing: A Russian Military Shake-Up
entries.description: Also, Brazil investigates the riots and Australia reacts to Cardinal George Pell’s death.

entries.title: Navalny’s Wife Pleads for Medical Treatment for Jailed Husband
entries.description: Yulia Navalny said that her ailing husband, Aleksei Navalny, was being held in a small cell with a sicker person to infect him, and was not allowed to lie down throughout the day despite having a fever.

entries.title: A Vital Question for Brazil’s Democracy: Where Were the Police?
entries.description: Their early inaction in Sunday’s riot shows how security forces can help empower violence and deepen the threat to democracy.

entries.title: Rehman Rahi, 97, Eminent Kashmiri Poet Who Restored a Language, Dies
entries.description: Kashmir’s unofficial poet laureate, he gave voice to the rich culture of a bitterly divided territory and helped give his mother tongue a distinct literary identity.

entries.title: Kyiv Workers Find Their Way Online Even as Ukraine Faces Power Outages
entries.description: Sporadic power outages have people resorting to makeshift office spaces in the Ukrainian capital. Stores have set up power hubs, and workers are getting comfortable doing their jobs in home furnishing displays.

entries.title: Zelensky Thanks the ‘Free World’ in a Message at the Golden Globes
entries.description: “There will be no third world war,” the Ukrainian president said. “It is not a trilogy. Ukraine will stop the Russian aggression on our land.”

entries.title: In Israel, Netanyahu’s Hard-Right Agenda Gains Steam
entries.description: Benjamin Netanyahu’s government is pushing to upend the judiciary, entrench Israeli control of the West Bank and strengthen ultraconservative Jews, fueling protests and deepening Israel’s divisions.

entries.title: Ukraine Strips a Pro-Putin Politician of His Citizenship
entries.description: Viktor Medvedchuk, a Ukrainian politician who is close to the Russian president, was handed over to Moscow in September as part of a prisoner swap while awaiting trial on treason charges.

entries.title: Ukraine Battles for Eastern Town as Russia Advances
entries.description: Ukraine denied Russian claims that it was losing control of Soledar, in the Donbas region. A victory there would be Russia’s first in months, after a string of humiliating losses.

entries.title: Another Big Boomer Effect
entries.description: One generation’s impact on the work force.

entries.title: They Won Guantánamo’s Supreme Court Cases. Where Are They Now?
entries.description: The three former Guantánamo prisoners who defeated George W. Bush at the Supreme Court in landmark cases are ensconced in family life. We caught up with two of them. One is a home-heating serviceman in central England; the other is an Uber driver in the French Riviera.

entries.title: ‘A Wild Card’: Son of Uganda’s President Jostles to Succeed His Father
entries.description: General Muhoozi Kainerugaba has been positioning himself as Uganda’s next leader. But his provocative tweets have unnerved Ugandans and put his father in a bind.

entries.title: Online Anger Over China’s Covid Pivot Shows Widening Social Split
entries.description: The Communist Party’s efforts to limit discord over its sudden “zero Covid” pivot are being challenged with increasing rancor, including from its own supporters.

entries.title: The New Soldiers in Propane’s Fight Against Climate Action: Television Stars
entries.description: An industry group is spending millions of dollars to push back against efforts to move heating away from oil and gas.

entries.title: W.H.O. Declares End to Uganda’s Worst Ebola Outbreak in Two Decades
entries.description: The virus spread to nine districts nationwide, infecting hundreds and killing dozens. Seven health workers were among those who died.

entries.title: Paris Police ‘Neutralize’ Man After Stabbings at Gare du Nord
entries.description: The man was arrested after injuring several people. It was not immediately clear what motivated the attack or how it unfolded.

entries.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
entries.description: At least 17 more civilians have died in extraordinary violence in Peru.

entries.title: Biden Defends His Immigration Policy as Summit in Mexico Wraps Up
entries.description: Even as President Biden and the leaders of Canada and Mexico sought to emphasize their shared commitments, the tricky issue of immigration dominated much of the discussion.

entries.title: George Pell, Cardinal Whose Abuse Conviction Was Overturned, Dies at 81
entries.description: An adviser to Pope Francis and a prominent figure in Australia, Cardinal Pell went to prison on charges of abusing two boys in the 1990s, but a higher court later acquitted him.

entries.title: Wagner Group Claims It Has Taken Soledar, an Eastern Ukrainian Town
entries.description: With a harsh winter putting sweeping offensives on hold, the war has shifted back to bloody battles of attrition like the one for the small city of Bakhmut and the smaller town of Soledar.

entries.title: Ukrainian Troops Will Travel to US to Learn to Operate Patriot Missile System
entries.description: After months of debate, the Biden administration said late last month that it was sending the Patriot system to Ukraine, responding to Kyiv’s urgent request to help defend against an onslaught of Russian missile and drone attacks.

entries.title: After Rocky Start, Biden Builds Rapport With Mexico’s President
entries.description: Warm gestures by the American president have helped cement a critical relationship with a Mexican leader whose cooperation on migration, climate change and the drug trade is crucial.
